Creating a Design System in Nuxt 3 with Tailwind CSS and ShadUI

Today, we're going to dive deep into creating a robust and flexible design system using the powerful combination of Nuxt 3, Tailwind CSS, and ShadUI. This trifecta offers a developer-friendly experience, unparalleled customization, and a component library that's both beautiful and accessible.

Why Nuxt 3, Tailwind CSS, and ShadUI?

Before we roll up our sleeves, let's understand why this particular stack is a winning combination for building a design system:

  • Nuxt 3: As a full-stack framework for Vue.js, Nuxt 3 provides a fantastic development experience with features like file-based routing, auto-imports, and server-side rendering (SSR) or static site generation (SSG). Its modular architecture makes it ideal for organizing and integrating a design system.
  • Tailwind CSS: This utility-first CSS framework empowers you to build designs directly in your markup without writing custom CSS. Its highly customizable nature means you can precisely define your design tokens (colors, spacing, typography, etc.) and apply them consistently across your application. The "constraints, not opinions" philosophy of Tailwind aligns perfectly with the principles of a design system.
  • ShadUI: While Tailwind provides the low-level utility classes, ShadUI (or similar headless UI libraries) offers beautifully designed, accessible, and unstyled components that you can fully theme with Tailwind CSS. This gives you the best of both worlds: pre-built, high-quality UI elements without the burden of overriding opinionated styles. It acts as a fantastic foundation for your design system's component library.

The Core Pillars of Our Design System

A successful design system isn't just a collection of components; it's a living document that defines your brand's visual language and interaction patterns. Here are the key pillars we'll focus on:

  1. Design Tokens: The atomic elements of your design system, such as colors, typography scales, spacing units, border radii, and shadows. These are directly mapped to Tailwind's configuration.
  2. Components: Reusable UI elements built with Nuxt 3, styled with Tailwind CSS, and potentially leveraging ShadUI for their underlying structure and accessibility.
  3. Documentation: Clear guidelines and examples for how to use the design tokens and components, ensuring consistency across teams and projects. This is crucial for adoption and maintainability.
  4. Tooling & Automation: Setting up development workflows, build processes, and potentially automated accessibility checks to streamline the design system's evolution.

Step-by-Step: Building Your Design System

Let's get practical! Here's a guided tour to setting up your design system.

1. Nuxt 3 Project Setup

If you don't have a Nuxt 3 project already, let's start with a fresh one:

Bash
npx nuxi init my-design-system-app cd my-design-system-app npm install

2. Integrating Tailwind CSS

Nuxt 3 makes integrating Tailwind CSS a breeze. Install the necessary packages:

Bash
npm install -D @nuxtjs/tailwindcss

Then, add it to your nuxt.config.ts:

TypeScript
// nuxt.config.ts export default defineNuxtConfig({ modules: [ '@nuxtjs/tailwindcss' ], tailwindcss: { cssPath: '~/assets/css/tailwind.css', // Optional: for custom base styles configPath: 'tailwind.config.js', viewer: true, // Enable Tailwind CSS viewer for development }, })

Create a tailwind.css file in assets/css if you want to include any base styles or @layer directives:

CSS
/* assets/css/tailwind.css */ @tailwind base; @tailwind components; @tailwind utilities;

Initialize your tailwind.config.js:

Bash
npx tailwindcss init -p

Now you have a tailwind.config.js file, which will be the heart of your design tokens.

3. Installing ShadUI

ShadUI components are unstyled by default, making them perfect for styling with Tailwind CSS. Installation typically involves installing the @radix-ui/vue primitives and a utility for cn (class name utility).

Bash
npm install -D @radix-ui/vue @nuxtjs/color-mode class-variance-authority tailwind-merge

You'll then want to configure color-mode and add shadcn-vue and ui directories to your content property in tailwind.config.js.

Crucially, for ShadUI, you generally follow their installation guide which involves running a CLI command to add components. This command typically configures your tailwind.config.js and sets up the necessary imports.

For example, to add a button component:

Bash
npx shadcn-vue add button

This command will often:

  • Add the Button component to your components/ui/button directory.
  • Update your tailwind.config.js to include the content path for ShadUI components.
  • Potentially add utility functions like cn to lib/utils.ts.

Important: Always refer to the official ShadUI documentation for the most up-to-date installation and component addition instructions.

8. Tooling and Best Practices

  • Linting & Formatting: Use ESLint and Prettier to enforce code style consistency.
  • TypeScript: Leverage TypeScript for strong typing, especially for component props and events.
  • Atomic Design Principles: Consider structuring your components using Atomic Design methodology (Atoms, Molecules, Organisms, Templates, Pages).
  • Version Control: Manage your design system in a dedicated repository or as a monorepo.
  • Accessibility (A11y): Integrate automated accessibility checks (e.g., axe-core) into your CI/CD pipeline and manually test with screen readers. ShadUI components are generally well-tested for accessibility.
  • Testing: Write unit and integration tests for your components.
  • Contribution Guidelines: Clearly define how other developers can contribute to and extend the design system.

The Benefits of a Design System

Investing time in building a design system with Nuxt 3, Tailwind CSS, and ShadUI offers significant returns:

  • Consistency: Ensures a unified brand experience across all your digital products.
  • Efficiency: Accelerates development by providing pre-built, tested components and clear guidelines.
  • Scalability: Easier to onboard new team members and expand your product suite.
  • Maintainability: Centralized updates to design tokens and components simplify global changes.
  • Collaboration: Fosters better communication between designers and developers.
  • Quality: Higher quality UI thanks to reusable, well-tested, and accessible components.

Conclusion

Creating a design system is an ongoing journey, not a one-time project. By leveraging the power of Nuxt 3 for its developer experience, Tailwind CSS for its unparalleled customization, and ShadUI for its robust and accessible components, you're building a solid foundation for a scalable, efficient, and beautiful product ecosystem.

Start small, iterate often, and remember that the most effective design systems are those that are actively used, maintained, and evolved by the teams that build with them. Happy designing and developing!

Creating a Design System in Nuxt 3 with Tailwind CSS and ShadUI

This guide will walk you through setting up Nuxt with Tailwind CSS and provide tips and best practices for making the most of this combination.

1. Setting Up Your Nuxt Project with Tailwind CSS

The easiest way to integrate Tailwind CSS into your Nuxt project is using the official @nuxtjs/tailwindcss module.

Step 1: Create a New Nuxt Project (if you haven't already)

npx nuxi init my-nuxt-tailwind-app
cd my-nuxt-tailwind-app

Step 2: Install Dependencies

npm install -D @nuxtjs/tailwindcss
npm install -D tailwindcss postcss autoprefixer

Step 3: Configure the Nuxt Tailwind Module

Open your nuxt.config.ts file and add @nuxtjs/tailwindcss to the modules array:

<!-- nuxt.config.ts -->
export default defineNuxtConfig({
  modules: [
    '@nuxtjs/tailwindcss'
  ]
})

Step 4: Configure Tailwind CSS

If you didn't have Tailwind CSS installed already, the @nuxtjs/tailwindcss module will likely prompt you to generate a tailwind.config.js file. If not, you can create it manually at the root of your project:

npx tailwindcss init -p

This will create two files: tailwind.config.js and postcss.config.js. You typically won't need to modify postcss.config.js unless you have other PostCSS plugins.

Step 5: Include Tailwind Directives in Your CSS

Create a global CSS file (e.g., assets/css/tailwind.css) and add the Tailwind CSS directives:

<!-- assets/css/tailwind.css -->
@tailwind base;
@tailwind components;
@tailwind utilities;

Step 6: Import the Global CSS File in nuxt.config.ts

Add the path to your CSS file in the css array of your nuxt.config.ts:

<!-- nuxt.config.ts -->
export default defineNuxtConfig({
  modules: [
    '@nuxtjs/tailwindcss'
  ],
  css: [
    '@/assets/css/tailwind.css'
  ]
})

Now, run your Nuxt development server:

npm run dev

You should now have Tailwind CSS fully integrated into your Nuxt project!

2. Tips and Best Practices for Nuxt and Tailwind CSS

Tip 1: Leverage Tailwind's Utility Classes Directly in Your Components

Embrace the utility-first approach of Tailwind CSS. Style your elements directly in your Vue templates using the provided classes:

<template>
  <div class="bg-gray-100 p-6 rounded-md shadow-md">
    <h2 class="text-xl font-semibold text-gray-800 mb-2">Welcome!</h2>
    <p class="text-gray-700">This is a simple card styled with Tailwind CSS.</p>
    <button class="bg-blue-500 hover:bg-blue-700 text-white font-bold py-2 px-4 rounded mt-4">
      Click Me
    </button>
  </div>
</template>

Tip 2: Customize Your Tailwind Configuration

Tailwind's power lies in its customizability. Modify your tailwind.config.js to match your project's design system:

<!-- tailwind.config.js -->
/** @type {import('tailwindcss').Config} */
module.exports = {
  content: [
    "./components/**/*.{js,vue,ts}",
    "./layouts/**/*.vue",
    "./pages/**/*.vue",
    "./plugins/**/*.{js,ts}",
    "./nuxt.config.{js,ts}",
    "./app.vue",
  ],
  theme: {
    extend: {
      colors: {
        primary: '#3490dc',
        secondary: '#ffed4a',
      },
      fontFamily: {
        sans: ['"Open Sans"', 'sans-serif'],
      },
    },
  },
  plugins: [],
}

Tip 3: Use Tailwind Directives for Custom Component Styles

While utility classes are great for quick styling, you might want to create reusable component styles. You can do this using Tailwind's @apply directive within your CSS:

<!-- assets/css/components.css -->
.btn-primary {
  @apply bg-blue-500 hover:bg-blue-700 text-white font-bold py-2 px-4 rounded;
}

.card {
  @apply bg-white rounded-md shadow-md p-6;
}

Then, import this components.css file (or whatever you name it) in your nuxt.config.ts:

<!-- nuxt.config.ts -->
export default defineNuxtConfig({
  modules: [
    '@nuxtjs/tailwindcss'
  ],
  css: [
    '@/assets/css/tailwind.css',
    '@/assets/css/components.css' // Import your custom component styles
  ]
})

Now you can use these custom classes in your templates:

<template>
  <div>
    <div class="card">
      <h2 class="text-xl font-semibold text-gray-800 mb-2">Card Title</h2>
      <p class="text-gray-700">Content of the card.</p>
      <button class="btn-primary mt-4">Action</button>
    </div>
  </div>
</template>

Tip 4: Take Advantage of Tailwind's Responsive Design Features

Tailwind makes responsive design straightforward with its breakpoint prefixes (e.g., sm:, md:, lg:, xl:).

<template>
  <div class="grid grid-cols-1 md:grid-cols-2 lg:grid-cols-3 gap-4">
    <div class="bg-gray-200 p-4">Item 1</div>
    <div class="bg-gray-200 p-4">Item 2</div>
    <div class="bg-gray-200 p-4 hidden md:block">Item 3</div>
  </div>
</template>

In this example, the layout will be a single column on smaller screens, two columns on medium screens, and three columns on large screens. The third item will be hidden on medium screens and below.

Tip 5: Use the safelist Option for Dynamic Class Generation (Carefully)

Sometimes, you might have classes that are generated dynamically and Tailwind's JIT (Just-In-Time) compiler might not pick them up during the scanning process. You can use the safelist option in your tailwind.config.js to explicitly include these classes:

<!-- tailwind.config.js -->
/** @type {import('tailwindcss').Config} */
module.exports = {
  content: [
    // ... your content paths
  ],
  safelist: [
    'bg-red-500',
    'text-lg',
    /^col-span-/ // Matches any class starting with 'col-span-'
  ],
  theme: {
    extend: {},
  },
  plugins: [],
}

Caution: Overusing safelist can increase your final CSS bundle size, negating some of the benefits of the JIT compiler. Only use it when necessary for dynamically generated classes.

Tip 6: Explore Tailwind Plugins

Tailwind has a vibrant ecosystem of plugins that can add pre-built components, typography enhancements, and more. You can install and configure them in your tailwind.config.js. For example, to add typography styles:

npm install -D @tailwindcss/typography

Then, in your tailwind.config.js:

<!-- tailwind.config.js -->
/** @type {import('tailwindcss').Config} */
module.exports = {
  content: [
    // ... your content paths
  ],
  theme: {
    extend: {},
  },
  plugins: [
    require('@tailwindcss/typography'),
  ],
}

Now you can use the prose class on an element containing your content for beautiful default typography.

Tip 7: Be Mindful of Class Length

While Tailwind encourages using many utility classes, sometimes a long string of classes can become less readable. Consider extracting reusable patterns using custom CSS with @apply if you find yourself repeating the same sets of utility classes frequently.

Tip 8: Inspect Element in Your Browser

The browser's developer tools are your best friend when working with Tailwind. Inspect elements to see which Tailwind classes are being applied and experiment with adding or removing classes directly in the "Styles" panel to quickly visualize changes.

A Detailed Guide to Nuxt and Tailwind

The Need for Caching

In modern web development, especially with Single Page Applications (SPAs) like those built with Nuxt 3, efficient data management is paramount. Fetching the same data repeatedly from an API can lead to:

  • Increased load times for users.
  • Higher bandwidth consumption.
  • Unnecessary strain on your backend infrastructure.

Caching solves these problems by storing the results of expensive operations (like API calls) and serving them from the cache on subsequent requests. This leads to faster load times and a smoother user experience.

Introducing Our Caching Utility

Let's look at the core of our caching mechanism. Below is the TypeScript code we'll be exploring:

                
type CacheEntry<T> = {
  value: T
  expiry: number
}

export type CacheOptions = {
  ttl?: number
  namespace?: string
  debug?: boolean
}

const DEFAULT_TTL = 3600 * 1000 // 1 hour
const DEFAULT_NAMESPACE = 'app-cache'

export const useCacheUtils = ({
  ttl = DEFAULT_TTL,
  namespace = DEFAULT_NAMESPACE,
  debug = false,
}: CacheOptions = {}) => {
  const cache = new Map<string, CacheEntry<any>>()
  const prefix = `${namespace}|`

  const log = (...args: unknown[]) => {
    if (debug) console.log('[cache]', ...args)
  }

  const getCacheKey = (operation: string, params: Record<string, unknown> = {}) => {
    const paramString = Object.entries(params)
      .sort(([a], [b]) => a.localeCompare(b))
      .map(([key, val]) => `${key}:${JSON.stringify(val)}`)
      .join('|')
    return `${prefix}${operation}|${paramString}`
  }

  const set = <T>(key: string, value: T, ttlOverride?: number): void => {
    const expiry = Date.now() + (ttlOverride ?? ttl)
    cache.set(key, { value, expiry })
    log('SET', key, value)
  }

  const get = <T>(key: string): T | null => {
    const entry = cache.get(key)
    if (!entry) {
      log('MISS', key)
      return null
    }
    if (entry.expiry < Date.now()) {
      log('EXPIRED', key)
      cache.delete(key)
      return null
    }
    log('HIT', key)
    return entry.value
  }

  const del = (key: string): void => {
    log('DELETE', key)
    cache.delete(key)
  }

  const clearExpired = (): void => {
    const now = Date.now()
    for (const [key, { expiry }] of cache.entries()) {
      if (expiry <= now) {
        log('CLEANUP', key)
        cache.delete(key)
      }
    }
  }

  const clearAll = (): void => {
    log('CLEAR ALL')
    cache.clear()
  }

  return {
    getCacheKey,
    set,
    get,
    del,
    clearExpired,
    clearAll,
  } as const
}

Dissecting the Code

Let's break down each part of our caching utility:

CacheEntry<T> Type

This TypeScript type defines the structure of an item stored in our cache:


type CacheEntry<T> = {
  value: T // The actual data being cached
  expiry: number // A Unix timestamp indicating when the cache entry expires
}

CacheOptions Type

This type defines the optional configurations you can pass when initializing the cache utility:


export type CacheOptions = {
  ttl?: number // Time-to-live in milliseconds for cache entries (default: 1 hour)
  namespace?: string // A prefix for all cache keys to avoid collisions (default: 'app-cache')
  debug?: boolean // Enables console logging for cache operations (default: false)
}

DEFAULT_TTL and DEFAULT_NAMESPACE

These constants provide default values for the cache's time-to-live (1 hour) and namespace ('app-cache').


const DEFAULT_TTL = 3600 * 1000 // 1 hour
const DEFAULT_NAMESPACE = 'app-cache'

useCacheUtils Function

This is the main composable function that sets up our caching logic. It accepts an optional CacheOptions object.


export const useCacheUtils = ({
  ttl = DEFAULT_TTL,
  namespace = DEFAULT_NAMESPACE,
  debug = false,
}: CacheOptions = {}) => {
  // ... implementation details
}

cache (Map)

At the heart of our utility is a JavaScript Map. This data structure efficiently stores key-value pairs, where the key will be our generated cache key and the value will be a CacheEntry.


  const cache = new Map<string, CacheEntry<any>>()

prefix

This string is used to prepend the namespace to every cache key, helping to avoid potential key collisions if you have multiple independent caching mechanisms in your application.


  const prefix = `${namespace}|`

log Function

A simple utility function to log cache operations to the console, but only when the debug option is set to true.


  const log = (...args: unknown[]) => {
    if (debug) console.log('[cache]', ...args)
  }

getCacheKey Function

This crucial function generates a unique key for each cached operation based on the operation name and any provided parameters. It ensures that different parameters for the same operation result in different cache entries. The parameters are sorted and stringified to create a consistent key regardless of the order in which they are provided.


  const getCacheKey = (operation: string, params: Record<string, unknown> = {}) => {
    const paramString = Object.entries(params)
      .sort(([a], [b]) => a.localeCompare(b))
      .map(([key, val]) => `${key}:${JSON.stringify(val)}`)
      .join('|')
    return `${prefix}${operation}|${paramString}`
  }

set Function

This function adds or updates an entry in the cache. It takes a key, a value to cache, and an optional ttlOverride to set a specific expiration time for this entry.


  const set = <T>(key: string, value: T, ttlOverride?: number): void => {
    const expiry = Date.now() + (ttlOverride ?? ttl)
    cache.set(key, { value, expiry })
    log('SET', key, value)
  }

get Function

This function retrieves a value from the cache based on the provided key. It checks if the entry exists and if it hasn't expired. If the entry is expired, it's automatically removed from the cache, and null is returned.


  const get = <T>(key: string): T | null => {
    const entry = cache.get(key)
    if (!entry) {
      log('MISS', key)
      return null
    }
    if (entry.expiry < Date.now()) {
      log('EXPIRED', key)
      cache.delete(key)
      return null
    }
    log('HIT', key)
    return entry.value
  }

del Function

This function removes a specific entry from the cache using its key.


  const del = (key: string): void => {
    log('DELETE', key)
    cache.delete(key)
  }

clearExpired Function

This function iterates through all cache entries and removes any that have expired.


  const clearExpired = (): void => {
    const now = Date.now()
    for (const [key, { expiry }] of cache.entries()) {
      if (expiry <= now) {
        log('CLEANUP', key)
        cache.delete(key)
      }
    }
  }

clearAll Function

This function clears the entire cache.


  const clearAll = (): void => {
    log('CLEAR ALL')
    cache.clear()
  }

Returned Object

Finally, the useCacheUtils function returns an object containing all these utility functions, making them easy to use within your Nuxt 3 components and composables.


  return {
    getCacheKey,
    set,
    get,
    del,
    clearExpired,
    clearAll,
  } as const

Use Cases and Examples

Where can you use this caching utility in your Nuxt 3 application?

Caching API Responses

The most common use case is caching the responses from your API endpoints. Let's imagine you have a function fetchUserProfile(userId: string) that fetches user data. You can cache the result like this:


import { useCacheUtils } from './cache-utils';

export default defineComponent({
  async setup() {
    const { getCacheKey, get, set } = useCacheUtils();
    const userId = 'user123';
    const cacheKey = getCacheKey('userProfile', { userId });

    const cachedData = get(cacheKey);
    if (cachedData) {
      console.log('Serving user profile from cache:', cachedData);
      return { user: cachedData };
    }

    const { data, error } = await useFetch(`/api/users/${userId}`);
    if (error.value) {
      console.error('Failed to fetch user profile:', error.value);
      return {};
    }

    if (data.value) {
      set(cacheKey, data.value);
      console.log('Fetched and cached user profile:', data.value);
      return { user: data.value };
    }

    return {};
  },
});

Caching Expensive Computations

If you have functions that perform computationally intensive tasks, you can cache their results based on the input parameters.


import { useCacheUtils } from './cache-utils';

const fibonacci = (n: number): number => {
  if (n <= 1) return n;
  return fibonacci(n - 1) + fibonacci(n - 2);
};

export const useCachedFibonacci = () => {
  const { getCacheKey, get, set } = useCacheUtils();

  return (n: number) => {
    const cacheKey = getCacheKey('fibonacci', { n });
    const cachedResult = get<number>(cacheKey);
    if (cachedResult !== null) {
      console.log(`Fibonacci(${n}) served from cache:`, cachedResult);
      return cachedResult;
    }

    const result = fibonacci(n);
    set(cacheKey, result);
    console.log(`Calculated and cached Fibonacci(${n}):`, result);
    return result;
  };
};

Controlling Cache Expiry

You can even set specific TTLs for different types of data if needed.


import { useCacheUtils } from './cache-utils';

export default defineComponent({
  async setup() {
    const { getCacheKey, get, set } = useCacheUtils();
    const newsFeedKey = getCacheKey('newsFeed');
    const cachedNews = get(newsFeedKey);

    if (cachedNews) {
      console.log('Serving news feed from cache.');
      return { news: cachedNews };
    }

    const { data, error } = await useFetch('/api/news');
    if (data.value) {
      // Cache news feed for only 5 minutes (300,000 milliseconds)
      set(newsFeedKey, data.value, 300000);
      console.log('Fetched and cached news feed.');
      return { news: data.value };
    }

    return {};
  },
});

What is Pocketbase?

Pocketbase is a free and open-source backend written in Go. It's designed to be a single file, making it incredibly easy to set up and deploy. Pocketbase provides:

  • A built-in database (SQLite).
  • A REST API.
  • User authentication.
  • File storage.
  • An admin panel.

It's an excellent choice for small to medium-sized projects, and it pairs perfectly with Nuxt 3 for building full-stack applications.

Setting up Pocketbase

First, you'll need to download the Pocketbase executable for your operating system from the official Pocketbase documentation. Follow the instructions there to download and extract the executable.

Initializing Pocketbase

Open your terminal, navigate to the directory where you extracted Pocketbase, and initialize it:


./pocketbase serve

This command will start the Pocketbase server and create a pb_data directory to store your database and files.

First-Time Login and Admin User

The first time you run ./pocketbase serve, Pocketbase will detect that no admin user exists. You'll be prompted in the terminal to create one. Follow the prompts carefully:


Admin email: your_email@example.com
Admin password: your_secure_password
Admin password confirm: your_secure_password

Enter your desired email address and a strong password. These credentials will give you full access to the Pocketbase admin panel.

Accessing the Admin Panel

Once the server is running, you can access the Pocketbase admin panel by opening your browser and navigating to http://127.0.0.1:8090/_/. Log in with the admin credentials you just created. This panel allows you to manage your database schema, users, and files through a user-friendly interface.

Creating the "posts" Collection in Pocketbase

Before we start interacting with data from our Nuxt 3 application, let's create a collection in Pocketbase to store our blog posts.

  1. Open the Pocketbase admin panel at http://127.0.0.1:8090/_/ and log in.
  2. On the left sidebar, click the + "Add new collection" button.
  3. In the "Name" field, enter posts (this is important as we'll use this name in our code).
  4. Choose "Base table" as the type.
  5. Click "Create".
  6. Now, let's add some fields to our "posts" collection. Click the "Add new field" button:
    • For the "title" field:
      • Type: "Text"
      • Name: title
      • You can leave the other options as default for now. Click "Save field".
    • For the "content" field:
      • Type: "Text"
      • Name: content
      • Consider making this a "Long text" type if your blog post content will be lengthy. Click "Save field".

You now have a "posts" collection with title and content fields.

Setting Permissions for the "posts" Collection

To allow our Nuxt 3 application to perform CRUD operations on the "posts" collection, we need to configure the permissions.

  1. In the Pocketbase admin panel, navigate to the "posts" collection.
  2. Click on the "Permissions" tab.
  3. Let's set the following basic permissions for this tutorial:
    • List: Set this to "Any" to allow anyone to read the list of posts.
    • Create: For simplicity in this tutorial, you can set this to "Any" to allow anyone to create a post. However, in a real application, you'd typically restrict this to authenticated users or admins.
    • View: Set this to "Any" to allow anyone to view individual posts.
    • Update: For this tutorial, you can set this to "Any". In a real application, you might want to allow only the creator or admins to update.
    • Delete: Similar to update, for simplicity, we'll set this to "Any" here. In a real application, you'd likely restrict this.
  4. Click "Save permissions".

Installing the Pocketbase JavaScript SDK

Now, let's install the Pocketbase JavaScript SDK in our Nuxt 3 project. Open a terminal in your Nuxt 3 project directory and run:


npm install pocketbase
# or
yarn add pocketbase
# or
pnpm add pocketbase

Creating the usePocketbase Composable

To make it easy to access the Pocketbase client throughout our Nuxt 3 application, we'll create a composable. Create a file named usePocketbase.ts in your composables directory (create the directory if it doesn't exist).


import PocketBase from 'pocketbase';
import { useRuntimeConfig } from '#app';

const POCKETBASE_URL = 'http://127.0.0.1:8090'; // Default, should be in config

let pb: PocketBase | null = null;

export const usePocketbase = () => {
    const config = useRuntimeConfig();
    const pocketbaseUrl = config.public.pocketbaseUrl || POCKETBASE_URL; // Use runtime config

    if (!pb) {
        pb = new PocketBase(pocketbaseUrl);
    }

    return pb;
};

Let's break down this code:

  • We import the PocketBase class from the pocketbase package.
  • We also import useRuntimeConfig from #app to access configuration values.
  • We define a POCKETBASE_URL constant as a fallback.
  • We declare a pb variable to hold our Pocketbase client instance (singleton pattern).
  • The usePocketbase function:
    • Gets the Pocketbase URL from the Nuxt runtime config (config.public.pocketbaseUrl). This allows you to configure the URL in your nuxt.config.ts file, making it easy to switch between development and production environments using environment variables.
    • If pb is null, it creates a new PocketBase client with the configured URL.
    • Returns the pb instance.

Configuring the Pocketbase URL in Nuxt

To properly configure the Pocketbase URL, open your nuxt.config.ts file and add the following:


export default defineNuxtConfig({
    runtimeConfig: {
        public: {
            pocketbaseUrl: process.env.POCKETBASE_URL || 'http://127.0.0.1:8090',
        },
    },
});

This code:

  • Uses defineNuxtConfig to configure Nuxt 3.
  • Sets the pocketbaseUrl in the public section of runtimeConfig, making it accessible client-side.
  • Prioritizes the POCKETBASE_URL environment variable if it's set (for deployment), falling back to http://127.0.0.1:8090 for local development.

Important: For production, you will need to set the POCKETBASE_URL environment variable on your hosting provider.

Implementing CRUD Operations with the usePocketbase Composable

Now, let's see how to perform Create, Read, Update, and Delete operations on our "posts" collection using the usePocketbase composable within a Nuxt 3 component or page.

Fetching Posts (Read)




<script setup>
import { ref, onMounted } from 'vue';
import { usePocketbase } from '@/composables/usePocketbase';

const pb = usePocketbase();
const posts = ref([]);

onMounted(async () => {
  try {
    const result = await pb.collection('posts').getList(1, 50); // Fetch up to 50 posts
    posts.value = result.items;
    console.log('Posts:', result);
  } catch (error) {
    console.error('Error fetching posts:', error);
  }
});
</script>

In this example, we fetch a list of posts when the component mounts and display them.
